title: 112_s170
content: The Act titled "Helping Responsible Homeowners Act" allows for affordable refinancing of mortgages owned or guaranteed by Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac. The "Helping Responsible Homeowners Act" defines key terms such as Director, Enterprise, and Qualified mortgage, which includes criteria for a qualified mortgage. The "Helping Responsible Homeowners Act" defines a qualified mortgage as an existing first mortgage on a one- to four-family dwelling, owned or guaranteed by Fannie Mae or Freddie Mac, with the mortgagor current on payments. The "Helping Responsible Homeowners Act" defines a qualified mortgage as an existing first mortgage on a one- to four-family dwelling, owned or guaranteed by Fannie Mae or Freddie Mac, with the mortgagor current on payments. A refinancing mortgage is a mortgage used to pay off all debt under an existing qualified mortgage and any associated closing costs. The principal loan amount secured by the mortgage is used to pay off existing indebtedness and closing costs from refinancing. The property subject to the mortgage must be the same as the qualified mortgage being refinanced. The mortgage must have a fair interest rate not exceeding 40 basis points. The mortgage being refinanced must be on the same property as the subject to the mortgage. The interest rate should not exceed 40 basis points above the required net yield for a prime conventional conforming fixed rate mortgage. The loan-to-value ratio of the mortgage must also meet certain criteria. The refinanced mortgage must be on the same property as the original mortgage. The interest rate should not exceed 40 basis points above the required net yield for a prime conventional conforming fixed rate mortgage. The mortgage shall not be limited by the loan-to-value ratio, and all prepayment penalties and fees related to default must be waived. The Federal National Mortgage Association and the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation will refinance qualified mortgages on single-family housing with a term to maturity of not more than 40 years. The Federal National Mortgage Association and the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation will refinance qualified mortgages on single-family housing through a program established by the Director of the Federal Housing Finance Agency. The Director of the Federal Housing Finance Agency will establish a program requiring the Federal National Mortgage Association and the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation to purchase or guarantee refinancing mortgages for qualified mortgages. The program prohibits charging mortgagees any up-front fees beyond the standard guarantee fee for refinancing. The Federal National Mortgage Association and the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation are prohibited from charging mortgagees any up-front fees beyond the standard guarantee fee for refinancing qualified mortgages. Servicers or creditors holding a second lien on a qualified mortgage must resubordinate the lien to allow for refinancing, or their new mortgages will be ineligible for purchase or guarantee by the Federal National Mortgage Association or the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation. The requirement for an enterprise to refinance qualified mortgages under this section shall not apply to any request for refinancing made after the expiration of the 1-year period beginning on the date of the enactment of this Act. The Director may extend the program established under this section in 1-year increments. The Director may extend the program established under this section in 1-year increments, and issue necessary regulations or guidance for its implementation. The Federal National Mortgage Association and the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation must ensure that mortgage servicers inform borrowers about the refinancing program. The Director will include updates on the program in the monthly Foreclosure Prevention & Refinance Report.
